instruction: Tell me about File Naming Best Practices
output: File names should be precise as NTFS file name size has a limit of 255 characters. This is a hard limit of the system that the Storage/Compute platform uses. Any files to be transferred to Storage/Compute need to be created following this limit or they cannot be transferred.

instruction: How do I login to RIS compute services?
output: The compute service uses the SSH protocol to one of several numbered access points with names like compute1-client-N, where N is a number. Here is an example of connecting to client-1: ssh wustlkey@compute1-client-1.ris.wustl.edu

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: A subscription tier is associated with a number of resources that are guaranteed for use based on the tier.

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: A condo queue is a queue associated with a purchased condo. More information about condos can be found here: https://ris.wustl.edu/services/compute/compute-condo/

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: The general queue runs batch jobs much like the traditional HPC setting. They run in the background in the queue system. The general queue also makes use of cache system, which you can learn more about here. Jobs in the general queue can run for up to 28 days.

instruction: Give me details on the given type of queue for RIS compute
output: The general-interactive queue runs jobs interactively so that you can interact directly with them or watch a job. The general-interactive queue does not use the cache system and instead interfaces with the Storage Platform directly. Jobs in the general-interactive queue can run for up to 24 hours.

instruction: Can I assign priority to the execution of my jobs on RIS Compute?
output: Yes. Use the -sp flag to set a numeric priority to the execution of your jobs. You can modify the priority of jobs in a pending state by using bmod -sp.

instruction: I have a large amount of jobs on RIS compute that are similar. How can I manage them?
output: When submitting a lot of similar jobs, they should submitted as an array. This allows you to easily submit and manage all of the jobs as a single entity. A single LSF bsub command is used to submit and can be altered with a single command as well. Each job in the array can also be accessed and modified individually if necessary.

instruction: Can RIS help me debug my software?
output: We strive to provide help with software debugging and support to the best of our abilities and time. With that being said, there may be times when we cannot solve an issue related to a specific piece of software or script that is not supported by RIS. In those cases, we will attempt to provide a solution to the problem, but we cannot guarantee that the solution will be successful.

instruction: What does it mean to have a RIS Compute Condo(minium)
output: Faculty members may purchase dedicated hardware for their labs to form what we refer to as a “condominium”. In this model, a “condo” is formed out of a set of hardware that we put into a Host Group. Then we create a pair of Queues named after the Lab, eg labname and labname-interactive. Then we create an AD group named compute-labname and populate it with Users. That group then gets priority access to that lab.

instruction: Why is RIS Compute $HOME limited to 10G? Can I have more?
output: User $HOME directories are intended to allow space for users to make use of the compute cluster, with the knowledge that the Storage Cluster is where data and software will be stored. This is accessed via /storage1, and the Scratch Cluster is accessed via /scratch1. The $HOME directory is NOT backed up and important data should NOT be stored here. Anything you wish to be backed up should be placed in /storage1, this includes scripts.

instruction: How do I see what is using up all of my RIS Compute $HOME space?
output: You can use the following command to list out the top 10 (or any number if you replace the 10) files or directories using the most space in your $HOME directory. Make sure the following command is run from your $HOME directory: du -hsx .[^.]* * 2>/dev/null | sort -rh | head -10

instruction: Why am I getting a Disk I/O error on RIS?
output: This error typically refers to the ability of the job to write a file to a directory. The most common source of the error is a user's home directory being full. If you encounter this error, please follow the steps below. /nUse the methods described in the home directory space section section to determine if the home directory is at cap. /nRemove or move files from the home directory to reduce usage. /nAttempt to run the job again. /nIf the problem persists, submit a ticket to the service desk: https://ris.wustl.edu/support/service-desk/

instruction: How do I share files in my storage with colleagues using RIS services?
output: You can request access be granted to your colleagues through our ticketing system: https://jira.wustl.edu/servicedesk/customer/portal/2/group/7. You can also use collections within Globus to share specific folders or files with colleagues. This method is the suggested method when it comes to colleagues outside of WashU. You can find more information about using this feature here: https://docs.ris.wustl.edu/doc/storage/globus.html

instruction: What is an LSF compute group?
output: A compute group is required for launching a job. RIS mediates access to services by compute groups, and you will be unable to submit a job if you are not part of one. You can find out what groups you are in by running: groups.

instruction: What is a docker container?
output: A container consists of an entire runtime environment: an application, plus all its dependencies, libraries and other binaries, and configuration files needed to run it, bundled into one package. By containerizing the application platform and its dependencies, differences in OS distributions and underlying infrastructure are managed. RIS compute1 uses Docker to manage containers.

instruction: What is RIS Archive Storage?
output: Archive storage is intended for long term data retention and NOT data that needs to be accessed regularly. Data moved to Archive resides on tape. Data being moved to Archive should be compressed via tar.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: Early-access features are limited to a closed group of testers for a limited subset of launches. Participation is by invitation only. These features may be unstable, change in backward-incompatible ways, and are not guaranteed to be released. There are no SLAs provided and no technical support obligations.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: Alpha is a limited-availability test before releases are cleared for more widespread use. Our focus with alpha testing is to verify functionality and gather feedback from a limited set of customers. Typically, alpha participation is by invitation and subject to pre-general-availability terms. Alpha releases don't have to be feature complete, no SLAs are provided, and there are no technical support obligations. However, alphas are generally suitable for use in test environments.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: At beta, products or features are ready for broader customer testing and use. There are no SLAs or technical support obligations in a beta release unless otherwise specified in product terms or the terms of a particular beta program.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: General availability products and features are open to all customers, covered by the RIS SLAs, and are ready for production use.

instruction: Tell me about a given RIS Product Launch Stage
output: Deprecated features are scheduled to be shut down and removed.

instruction: What is WUSTL Secure Enclave?
output: The WUSTL Secure Enclave service is designed to support the Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC) (inclusive of NIST Special Publication 800-171) framework defined by the Department of Defense as a way to verify compliance to protect Controlled Unclassified Information (CUI). Click here to learn more: https://ris.wustl.edu/controlled-unclassified-information/

instruction: When should I use RIS Compute's general queue?
output: Usually, the general queue is for running jobs with large amount of resource requirements. The general queue is for running large numbers of jobs, especially the same analysis on multiple samples. The general queue is NOT for GUI related software or interactive sessions.

instruction: What happens if I go over the guaranteed resources for my RIS Compute Subscription queue Tier?
output: If you go over on the number of guaranteed vCPUs for a job submitted in this queue type, your job will not be guaranteed to run. If you go over on the number of guaranteed GPUs for a job, your job will stay in pending and never run.

instruction: What are RIS Storage Snapshots?
output: Within the Active storage tier there is a directory named .snapshots that contains one week of daily snapshots of the Active storage space. If files in your Active space get overwritten, corrupted, or mistakenly deleted, you can copy previous versions out of the .snapshots directory back into Active.

instruction: What are RIS Storage Tape Backups?

instruction: How do I use CPU resources for RIS Compute?
output: By default, a job will use any CPU that is available to run the job. If a job has specific CPU architecture resource requirements, one can specify a CPU architecture with the rusage expression: > bsub -q foo-condo -R 'select[model==Intel_Xeon_Gold6242CPU280GHz]' -a 'docker(alpine)' /bin/true

instruction: Why should I make a job group within RIS Compute?
output: It frequently happens that we want to run a resource-intensive process on hundreds or thousands of data sets. In some cases, the load this imposes on the system will become apparent to other users. They will experience increased latency if their data lives on the same filesystem. Using job groups you can create the effect of a personal queue.

instruction: Is there a slot limit for RIS Compute Users?
output: The Compute Platform has a limit of 500 slots per user. This essentially means 500 vCPUs. This is across all jobs. For example, you can have 500 jobs running with 1 vCPU each, or 10 jobs running with 50 vCPUs each, or 1 job running with 500 vCPUs, and if you are using 490 vCPUs and a job you submit needs 15, it will sit in queue until your total is 485 or less.

output: To see which (if any) hosts have enough resources to handle jobs you'd like to submit, use the bhosts -R command. For example, the below query lists all hosts in the foo-condo host group that have at least 25GB of unreserved memory, 25GB of free memory and 10GB of local disk space: bhosts -R 'select[mem>25000 && free_memory_mb>25000 && tmp>10]' foo-condo

instruction: Can I run interactive and batch jobs for RIS Compute that output to the same directory?
output: No. Given the diffent methods of connecting to the RIS Storage cluster between the client and interactive nodes, and the batch nodes (general queue) and condos, this could lead to filesystem conflicts.

instruction: Is there a way to store my envrionment variables for RIS Compute jobs?
output: You can permanently store these settings by including them in your ~/.bashrc file where they will be loaded each time you log in. But be sure to remember that they are there. Historically, users forget what's in their .bashrc, and when systems change, updates to .bashrc may be required. Consider reminding yourself they are present with an 'echo' statement.
